Employment

Workplace Discrimination or Harassment

What to know about discrimination and harassment at work

Your Rights

5 rights in this scenario

Your employer cannot treat you unfairly because of your race, color, religion, sex, or national origin. This includes hiring, firing, pay, promotions, and day-to-day treatment. Discrimination based on pregnancy is also illegal. Document all incidents with dates and witnesses.

ðŸ’¡ This right has state-specific variations. Select a state to see relevant details.

Source: Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964

The Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC) is a federal agency that investigates discrimination complaints. You can file for free. You typically must file within 180-300 days depending on your state. Filing triggers an investigation into your employer's practices.

ðŸ’¡ This right has state-specific variations. Select a state to see relevant details.

Source: Title VII and EEOC Authority (29 U.S.C. Â§ 706)

If you have a disability, your employer must make reasonable changes to help you do your jobâ€”like flexible scheduling, accessible bathrooms, or equipment modificationsâ€”unless it causes undue hardship. This includes mental health conditions and temporary disabilities. Request accommodation in writing when possible.

ðŸ’¡ This right has state-specific variations. Select a state to see relevant details.

Source: Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) of 1990

Your employer cannot punish you for reporting discrimination, harassment, unsafe conditions, or illegal activity. Retaliation includes termination, demotion, reduced hours, or any negative employment action. Report retaliation immediately to your HR or a lawyer.

Source: Title VII Anti-Retaliation Provision (42 U.S.C. Â§ 2000e-3)

Men and women must receive equal pay for equal work. Equal work means jobs requiring the same skill, effort, and responsibility performed under similar working conditions. If you discover a pay gap, you can file a claim. Keep records of your pay and comparable employees' pay if you know it.

ðŸ’¡ This right has state-specific variations. Select a state to see relevant details.

Source: Equal Pay Act of 1963
